p: The development of portable electronic devices urgently requires lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with a high capacity and long lifespan [ 1, 2, 3]. Currently, extensive efforts have been devoted to developing alternative anode materials, e.g., metal oxide, alloys and group IVA elements, to boost the capacity of LIBs [ 1, 4, 5]. Micro-pillar splitting and micro-cantilever bending have been proposed to evaluate the mechanical behaviors of materials at the micro-scale, and micro-pillar splitting is commonly employed to analyze the fracture toughness of battery electrode materials and solid state electrolyte [ 6]. Tin (Sn) is regarded as one of the promising anode substitutes due to its high theoretical gravimetric capacity (994 mA h g −1 for Li 22Sn 5), low cost, great safety and low working potential window (0.3–0.6 V) [ 7, 8, 9]. However, Sn suffers from violent irreversible capacity loss and disintegration due to its Li-driven volume expansion (up to 259%) during lithiation and de-lithiation cycling, which impedes its application in commercial LIBs [ 7, 10].
